reviews.review_msg: Course has a lot of information and a lot of work for a first year course. I took this as an elective to raise my gpa and sadly the only thing it did was drop it. TA was an incredibly picky and hard marker. Tried reaching out for some assistance and professor was rude and very blunt in telling me to help myself.

Prof. Keough was a good professor. The lectures were a bit boring though. As they were asynchronous, it made it difficult to get immersed in the materials. Unless you thoroughly enjoy reading further into this kind of material I recommend against buying the text, you probably will not use it. I also did not watch even half of the lectures for this.

Willeen is very passionate about her classes. She does go off on a tangent here and there and tends to talk a lot so it gets a little boring. But she is very supportive and accessible outside of class. She gives very detailed feedback about essays and has a solid grading criteria she gives in the beginning so you know her expectations.

Wouldn't say HIST 101 is the greatest class to take with Prof Keough as her lectures are pre-recorded (Asynchronous) and can get quite dry/boring. The tutorial was super chill if you have a good TA. Lots of reading, but Ta's went over it during tutorials (Make sure you went to get answers) Otherwise, pretty easy, only 2 big papers and one final.

Prof. Keough is a caring and passionate prof, though her lectures are based mainly from the textbook (which I didn't use - lectures and articles are enough if you pay attention & take notes). The course is heavy and dry at times. Optional live discussions are more fun than the mandatory discussion board posts. If possible, in-person >>> online.

Dr. Keough was tough but fair. This course may be a bit heavy for first years, but overall it was not terribly difficult. Do NOT bother going to tutorials. They are not required and they are a waste of time, but I do recommend attending office hours. Overall a solid course.

Not really impressed with the amount of work that was expected for this class. It's a first-year class in a pandemic but it didn't feel like it. Not to mention due to our TA's error, our participation grades had to be curved down, awesome.

Dont take! Does not use appropriate language/context for Indigenous People and the max you will get on an assignment is 80-89%. Also, considering we are in a pandemic profs were expected to lighten the course load and she did NOT! She started a week early and expected students to write 3 essays as a first year final in a short time frame.

Wonderful speaker. Usually lecture heavy but promotes discussion and questions. Expects some level of participation, usually in the form of reading responses. Lots of fun, engaged, and treats students with care and respect. 10/10.

Great lecturer, good at prompting discussion when needed but explains things thoroughly so that the lectures, coupled with the readings, are informative enough to get you through. She's very nice! Listening to her lecture is a pleasure because she speaks w/ the poetic cadence of a Newfoundlander that keeps you interested in even the dullest topic.

Lectures feel as though they will never end... but she is a nice lady and helpful towards students. She based some of her lectures off a textbook which she did not tell us about - but we were given a diff textbook to read for the class requirement. I don't understand why, but that's what it was. Didn't turn out too bad though.
Forwarning her lectures are very dry and boring. However, the one thing I would recommend to any student taking her course is to go to her office hours as she was extremely helpful with the papers.
Exams based on lectures.  Lectures dry, but she did her best to make it interesting.

The lectures were dry and boring, however she did her best to keep it moving.  Slides were good, but not available online.  Lectures recorded and available.  The readings for tutorial were extensive and tough to keep up with for a first year class.  Exam questions are given ahead of time, so you can prepare well for your answers.

I took this class last fall, and although I received a decent grade, I did not really enjoy the class. I liked the way Willeen set up her lecture slides, but the fact that we had no midterm and just a final made it hard to remember all the materials. She is a nice lady, and the worst part of the course was the tutorials.

The course was relatively boring, yet required for PDP. However, Keough was pretty great. The TA I had was a brutal marker though; average for both papers in our tutorial was low C+. Keough is clear about all papers, readings, exam expectations and other material. Never spoke personally, but  helped me via email regarding my paper. Decent lectures.

Lectures with her were the worst part of my semester. They were so dead and dry... and she doesn't post notes online and told us her lectures would be in the final...so i attended every one. Final came...and I didn't even LOOK at the lec notes -__- all you need is the textbook. tutorial readings are way too excessive for 1st year..

Lectures right from textbook but she kept it fairly interesting; notes easy to read. Final exam was easy but your grade depends on your TA. She does help if you email her or approach her after lectures and is generally very useful

She seems approachable. Wasn't that interested in all the lecture material but there were some interesting lectures. In my opinion, the tutorial readings every week were too much for a first year history class. No marks back yet and haven't written the final though, so haven't fully decided my opinion on the class yet lol
Willeen is a nice enough lady, although her lectures and the class itself was quite dry. The tutorials were dreadful and the readings soooo dull.

This woman is perfectly suited to teaching Canadian history. An incredibly boring subject with an incredibly boring woman teaching it. The topic of Canadian history is one that needs a certain electric personality to teach it in order for any of the insanely dull material to get through to the students. Willeen unfortunately doesn't have that personality and though she tries, it's just a painfully uninteresting experience.

Super nice professor, but seemed even more bored of the lectures than most of the students. Classes began late and finished early, and others were cancelled altogether. The expectations for assignments were not clear, and my TA seldom attended lectures and so couldn?t answer questions very well.

Great teacher who uses her Newfoundland background to liven up classes. Readings are quite long for tutorials and those who don't like history will not like them. Had 2 short papers and a final (questions given in advance).Go to her office hours as she gives you much more information than she should... she basically told me how to write my 2nd pape

Lectures are a bit dry, but it's just the content, not the prof. She has very organized slides. Very easy to follow. 2 assignments in the course; one is primary source analysis and second is secondary source comparison. Not too much reading in a week. She cares a lot about her students and is very approachable. She obviously knows the content.
Her marking is very very arbitrary.  I would not recommend this class to anyone unless you're in Arts.  But even then, the material is pretty dry.

Willeen is an awesome professor who really cares about her undergraduate students. She's always available and tries to get discussion going without talking too much. The readings were fun and there wasn't too much of it.

Good teacher. Material comes straight from ppt slides. 2 essays during the sem, approx 8 pg each. TA WAS EXTREMELY BAD. exam was easy- 2 essay questions which she gives in advance. recommend her for ppl who want to get into PDP since she's clear & concise in her teaching and is a decent marker. watch out for TA's, seriously.

Biggest sweetheart in the world. Cares about every student, cares about the content ... just cares. Very understanding. Adds humour to lectures to keep the class paying attention. Ensnaring teaching style. Reading load more than reasonable for an upper level class. I'd take another class with this woman in a heartbeat.

I am SO glad to be done with this course. Dreaded the boring readings and lectures, tutorial discussions, and essay writing. However, I actually ended up with a pretty good mark... ONLY because of the help of my friends. TA was useless.

She's nice but condescending.  Course is all writing even though it's not a W course.  Course material is boring, book is not mandatory, absolutely useless, attendance isn't mandatory either.  TAs have a skewed marking scheme, if your opinion doesn't match theirs then they'll mark your paper down.

This class is pure fail.  I don't know why it isn't labeled as a W course since there's more writing in this course than an actual W course.  90% of the marks are from writing essays, the final is made up of 3 essays.  Not only is this class boring, unless you're really good at writing, don't bother with this course.  TA's don't know how to mark.

Willeen is a nice person and tries to make the transition from high school easier, but this was def not what I expected for a first year course. There was a ton of reading to do every week. Unless you like reading and analyzing secondary and primary documents, don't take this course. The second assignment was HARD, and the TA was not too helpful.
Good course, good prof. Comes across as a bit condendending at times, but that's a minor complaint.
Good lecturer. Very clear notes on overhead. Easy going class.
Clear about expectations, gave an interesting lecture and gave very constructive criticism when marking assignments. Very helpful! Overall, she is just a really good person!

Willeen is a great prof altho she tries to scare you off the 1st day. She's very smart, helpful, and easy to talk to. Her assignments are clear & straightforward, not too hard but not too easy either. She was very passionate about this topic (NFLD) since that's where she's from originally. Overall, I recommend her. Nice person, interesting class.

The ratings suggest this is an easy prof. NOT TRUE. Lectures were boring and instead of midterms, she had 2 papers where you had to read a bunch of boring sources and critically analyze them. Not what I was expecting in a 1st yr course at all. The only things I can commend her on are hiring a cool TA and trying to make the jump to university easier

The class itself is really pretty boring, but that is the material- not the professor. She tries to make the best of the material, and is very understanding. She doesn't expect you to memorize everything. Tutorials require work but are interesting- though a little unrelated to lectures.
Great course! Remember it is Canadian pre confed so don't expect anything thrilling, but i've sat through worse lectures. Willeen is very nice and approachable for help. I would recomend this course.

She doesn't seem to be very interested in the content she is teaching. As a result her lectures are rather dull. Assignments and course readings are fair, and the class is fairly easy. All in all, an ok teacher but needs to work on her enthusiasm.

If you're uncertain about taking history - you're one of those chubs who think history is hard because you can't write a good essay - then take this course. it's one of those courses where everything's explained to you while the content isn't overly demanding. plus, keough's a great professor so thumbs up.
Boring lectures but she makes kick ass notes, her midterms were fair but her final was easy as pie. Overall a pretty good course.
A little boring, but teacher is easy to follow and so I thought over all the class was good.

Despite being Irish myself, I found the course pretty dry. Lots of treaties, agricultural issues, and other standard topics. Perhaps my expectations for the material were too high. The prof is great though - organized, interested in the material, and knowledgeable - almost a teacher per se, in contrast to the 'lecturers' who do nothing to help you.

I wasn't interested in Canadian History before taking her course.  She managed to make the information excessable and worth learning.  The material may have been dry, but her lectures still managed to keep me interested.  I liked her organization and power-point presentations...It helped us visual learners retain auditory information!!!

If all profs were as organized and clear we'd all have a good chance at getting A's. Made sure to cover wymns + aboriginal content thoroughly. Her lectures are pretty much from the book but that helps solidify the concepts and content in your head. Can be funny and easy to talk to. An A from me. Ta was good too her name Rachel Torrie.
Great first year prof. Dont be shy to sit down with her and talk if you are unhappy with your grade. She's great, funny and understanding.

Prof Keough was one of the most helpful profs I've had in my 4 years in post secondary. If you are new to university and she is teaching an intro course, I would recommend that you take it with her. She might spoon feed you a little which the older folks don't like, but she still improves critical thinking skills. Content made the class dull.

She is a really kind and nice. Though her lectures tend to be on the boring side. She was kind of rushing through her slides most of the time, but she did go back to let us copy everything down. Was clear on what she expected in essay assignments. I think the marking and the easiness of the course depends on the TA and not really Dr Keough.

She's a spoon feeder, but I wish more were in first year - considering the HUGE jump in terms of expectations from High School to Univ, you NEED more profs like this who can introduce you to the expectations of Univ. without terrifying you. She's kind, helpful, but yes - very dull - but only because Canada is a really dull country.

She makes things easy for you, I admit. I appreciated that when I had lots of work in my other classes.  It is a first year class so remember that.  She has a dry sense of humor and I don't think everybody gets it.  I liked her class because she was very upfront about what she wanted.  If you can't pass this class, you're an idiot.

Make sure you take this in your first year if you do. Good proff for people who are new to the university experience, though she spoils students a bit more than she should. If you're not new to uni, or like a challenge, you'll die of boredom and frustration: she's a slow lecturer, repeditive as hell, and doesn't offer anything new on subject for.

I don't know why people think 'spoon feeding' students is such a bad thing. She's an excellent professor, very compassionate and adds a funny remark now and then. I hated Canadian history though for some reason I managed to pull a B so far in her class. Coincidence?
She is very sympathetic to students needs.  Except when she makes fun of you afterwards.  Lectures are boring, if you dont pay attention you fail the midterm, unless you read the textbook.
A very enjoyable first year class. Her was very clear in what she wanted done for all assignments and her tests were pretty fair. A very nice person who tought a very nice class.
Boring class, boring professor. Takes her notes straight from the textbook.  Spoon feeds absolutely everything to you.  Easy enough class but deathly boring lectures.
No Comments

Drop dead easy course. She spoon feeds the new kids. This is a good thing, since most profs expect new students to immediately make the jump from high school style. Though very helpful, and clearly wanting you to learn, she effectively 'reads from the book' during lecture, making it dull as paint drying and often ambiguous as to what's important.
